title: Domain 1.8: Explain common OS types and their purposes.
content:
üíª Workstation Operating Systems

  • Windows: Most common for business and personal use. User-friendly, wide software compatibility.
  • Linux: Open-source, secure, and customizable. Preferred for servers and power users.
  • macOS: Apple‚Äôs desktop OS, optimized for creative work and Apple hardware.
  • Chrome OS: Lightweight, browser-based. Great for web tasks on Chromebooks.

üì± Mobile Operating Systems

  • iPadOS: iOS variant for iPads. Enhanced for productivity and multitasking.
  • iOS: Smooth, secure OS for iPhones.
  • Android: Google‚Äôs open-source OS. Highly customizable, runs on many devices.

üìÇ File System Types

  • NTFS: Windows default. Supports permissions, large files, encryption, and journaling.
  • FAT32: Cross-platform compatibility, but limited to 4GB files.
  • ext3: Common Linux FS with journaling.
  • ext4: Faster, more efficient than ext3. Supports larger files and volumes.
  • APFS: Optimized for SSDs on macOS/iOS. Strong encryption and snapshots.
  • exFAT: No 4GB file limit, ideal for external drives. Widely supported.

‚è≥ Vendor Life-Cycle Limitations

  • End-of-Life (EOL): Vendor ends support and updates.
  • Update Limitations: Hardware or license restrictions may block newer updates.

‚ö†Ô∏è Compatibility Between OSs

Different operating systems may have trouble with:

  • Running the same software
  • Hardware driver support
  • Accessing file systems (e.g., macOS can't write to NTFS without third-party tools)
